did.unittitle: James and Sybil Irwin family papers 1815-1987, 1832-1946
did.abstract: James and Sybil (Hunter) Irwin were early setters of Washtenaw County, Michigan. Their two sons, John E. and (James) Leman Irwin, fought in the Civil War as volunteer members of the 20th Michigan Infantry. Correspondence, diaries, and ledgers from these and other branches of the family are preserved in the Irwin family papers.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from the heirs of James and Sybil Irwin (donor no. 7476) in August and September 2007.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, James and Sybil Irwin family papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Irwin family were early settlers of Washtenaw County, Michigan. James Irwin was born in New York in 1810 and removed to Saline, Michigan in 1831. His wife, Sybil Hunter, came to Michigan from New York with her parents in 1832.

James and Sybil (Hunter) Irwin had two sons, John E. and (James) Leman Irwin, who would each enlist as soldiers in the Civil War as volunteers in the 20th Michigan Infantry. (James) Leman Irwin died in combat in the early days of the Siege of Petersburg, 17 June 1864. A daughter, Harriet S. (Hattie) Irwin, became a schoolteacher and lived for some time in Nevada. The veteran John E. Irwin married Amy Rice and lived in Michigan for the remainder of his life. They had two sons: Max H. and Fred C. Irwin. In 1890 and 1891 Max H. and Fred C. Irwin prospected on the Iron Range of Northern Minnesota.

scopecontent.p: The James and Sybil Irwin family papers feature letters written from various Civil War battlefields and encampments by the brothers John E. and (James) Leman Irwin. There are four additional Civil War letters from cousins Samuel H. Row, James H. Irwin, S. Baker, and S.H. Loveland, as well as a transcription of William B. Irwin's journal. The collection also provides insight into the lives of Michigan farmers in the second half of the 19th Century and early 20th Century by way of letters, ledgers, photographs, and diaries. In addition, the correspondence record details the experience of prospectors on the Minnesota Iron Range and life on a Great Lakes freighter. Also extant are sketches by Harriet (Hattie) Irwin, poetry by Harriet and Civil War veterans John E. Irwin and Samuel H. Row, and some early documents pertaining to the North Sharon Methodist Episcopal Church.

The James and Sybil Irwin family papers are divided into the following series largely as maintained by the donor: Civil War Materials; the Baker-Rice and Irwin Families; the individuals Amy (Rice) Irwin, Fred C. Irwin, Harriet S. Irwin, Isaac Irwin, James and Sybil (Hunter) Irwin, John E. Irwin, Max H. Irwin, (James) Leman Irwin, and Max H. Irwin; the North Sharon Methodist Episcopal Church; Miscellaneous items; and Postcards.

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Army. Michigan Infantry Regiment, 20th (1862-1865). Company C.
United States. Army. Michigan Infantry Regiment, 20th (1862-1865). Company F.
United States. Army. Michigan Infantry Regiment, 26th (1862-1865). Company H.

scopecontent.p: The Civil War Materials series contains both the original letters and Maxine (Irwin) White's typed and indexed transcription of the correspondence of brothers John E. and (James) Leman Irwin, who fought in the Civil War as volunteer members of the 20th Michigan Infantry. Also included is an 1864 field journal by John E. Irwin. There is also a typed transcription of the journal of William Bradford Irwin (William B. Irwin of Delhi, Michigan enlisted in Company H, 26th Michigan Infantry, 13 Sept. 1862, at Mason, Michigan. The location of the original diary is not known).The series also contains materials that have not been transcribed, such as correspondence from the front written by relatives James H. Irwin of New York, Company I 1st Veteran Cavalry, S.H. Loveland of the 8th Michigan Infantry, and S. Baker. Also included is a letter from veteran cousin Samuel H. Row to John E. Irwin shortly after the close of the war in 1865, 20th Michigan Infantry ephemera, applications for bounty on behalf of deceased sons filed by James Irwin and Orrin Row, and an 1864 ledger kept by John E. Irwin.

scopecontent.p: Amy (Rice) Irwin was born in Stockbridge, Michigan on 30 June 1848, the daughter of John W. and Mary (Baker) Rice and daughter-in-law of James and Sybil Irwin. She married John E. Irwin in 1869 and died 21 September 1927, surviving her husband by eight years. Throughout her life she maintained a correspondence network with many members of her family.

scopecontent.p: Fred C. Irwin was born about 1870, the son of John E. and Amy (Rice) Irwin, and grandson of James and Sybil Irwin. He graduated from Grass Lake High School in June 1889, prospected in Northern Minnesota in 1890 and 1891, and attended Annapolis Naval Academy.

Teacher's Certificates and Correspondence from Students 1889-1933
Fred C. and Max H. Irwin

scopecontent.p: Some letters of Fred C. and Max H. Irwin were filed together, and this series reflects the original order. In 1890 and 1891 the brothers prospected on the Iron Range of Northern Minnesota and a large set of correspondence with their parents details this experience.

did.unittitle: Incoming from J. E. Longyear re: Minnesota

scopecontent.p: Harriet S. Irwin, also known as Hattie, was the daughter of James and Sybil Irwin, born about 1845. She lived in Michigan as well as Duckwater and Eureka, Nevada, frontier "boom towns" about 200 and 260 miles north of Las Vegas, working as a schoolteacher for the families of miners and prospectors. Preserved within this series are her correspondence, diaries, poetry, and some sketches.

did.unittitle: Incoming from Lucy Maria (Carpenter) Jones and Miriam/ May (Carpenter) Harris 1865-1868

odd.p: (incl. Edwin E. Row and Alice Stundon)

scopecontent.p: Isaac Irwin was the brother of James Irwin and the uncle of Harriet (Hattie) Irwin. Like his niece, Isaac lived in Duckwater and Eureka, Nevada. He also lived in Cape Cod, Massachusetts.

James and Sybil (Hunter) Irwin were very early settlers in Washtenaw County, Michigan. James Irwin was born in New York in 1810, the son of John Irwin, and removed to Saline, Michigan in 1831. Many of his siblings remained in New York, and a collection of correspondence from the 1830's and 1840's remains. He married Sybil Hunter in 1836, the daughter of Nathaniel and Rhoda (Peck) Hunter. She came to Michigan from New York with her parents in 1832. The Irwins would live in Freedom Township, Sharon Township, and Grass Lake, Michigan. James and Sybil Irwin had two sons, John E. and (James) Leman Irwin, who fought in the Civil War ((James) Leman Irwin died in combat), and a daughter, Harriet S. (Hattie) Irwin, became a schoolteacher and lived for some time in Duckwater and Eureka, Nevada.

odd.p: (incl. Elizabeth Dickinson, Row family, Miriam (Carpenter) Harris, and others)

Maple Hill Cemetery Association of Grass Lake, Receipt 1888

scopecontent.p: John E. Irwin was born 9 May 1841 in Freedom Township, the son of James and Sybil Irwin, and attended the Normal School in Ypsilanti. He enlisted 20 July 1862 in Company B, Twentieth Michigan Infantry. This company would fight with Morgan's Guerillas and Horseshoe Bend, participated in the sieges of Vicksburg and Knoxville, march with the Army of the Potomac as it advanced toward Richmond, and served under General Grant during the Battle of the Wilderness and Battle of Spotsylvania Court House. John E. Irwin was wounded during the Siege of Petersburg (his brother, (James) Leman, died during this battle) but continued fighting and achieved the rank of Second Lieutenant before being discharged on 1 June 1865. He married Amy Rice in Michigan in 1869 and they had two sons: Max H. and Fred C. Irwin. Like his parents, he was a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church and was a prohibitionist. John E. Irwin was also an active member of the Grand Army of the Republic, Post No. 228. He died about 1919. Items in the John E. Irwin series span the length of his life - from an elementary school reader to letters written from his travels with the G.A.R. later in life. An exchange of correspondence with his cousin, Samuel H. Row, also a Civil War veteran, contains epic poetry about their Civil War experiences.

scopecontent.p: (James) Leman Irwin, son of James and Sybil Irwin, enlisted in company F, 20th Michigan Infantry, as a fifer 6 Aug. 1862 and was killed in action during the first days of the Siege at Petersburg, 18 June 1864. This series includes some pre-Civil War correspondence (his Civil War letters are in the Civil War Materials series).

did.unittitle: Outgoing to Cousin Samuel H. Row 1861

scopecontent.p: Max H. Irwin was born 15 November 1873, the son of John E. and Amy (Rice) Irwin, and grandson of James and Sybil Irwin. He prospected in Northern Minnesota in 1890 and 1891 and worked on the Great Lakes in 1903.

did.unittitle: Incoming, mostly from nephew Charles Irwin 1903-1945
Outgoing (with some incoming) to Brother Fred and Mother Amy 1911-1943

scopecontent.p: James Irwin was involved in the formation of the North Sharon Methodist Episcopal Church and helped organize their Sunday School program. These records and others are extant in this series.

The Miscellaneous series includes items from the Irwin collection which were not directly related to the immediate family of James and Sybil (Hunter) Irwin, including correspondence from the Berry and Carpenter families and a set of early Washtenaw County deeds. Also included is a ledger book from Sharon Mills (proprietors Rice and Champlin), dated 1856-1867, an account book dated 1831-1832, and an assortment of loose photographs, poetry, and recipes.
